title: Jeremy Corbyn faces 18-point Tory lead over Labour with crucial by-elections just days away
text:

Jeremy Corbyn faces increasingly disastrous polling numbers just days ahead of the crunch Copeland and Stoke by-elections 
A Guardian/ICM poll , published today showed Labour trailing by 18 points behind the Tories. 
It represents one of the four worst results for the party since the monthly poll launched in 1983, just before Michael Foot’s historic drubbing at the hands of Margaret Thatcher. 
The Tories are up two points in the survey, with 44%, while Labour are down one point at 26%. 
That’s just 1% higher than their lowest poll share ever. Voting intention Guardian/ICM 
It will make troubling reading for the Labour leader, who faces two crucial by-election tests on Thursday. 
Party campaigners are optimistic of holding on to Stoke following the recent meltdown of their main rival, Ukip leader Paul Nuttall, but are fearful of losing Copeland to the Tories. Read More 
It would be the first time a governing party has won a seat from the Opposition in a by-election since the Tories won Mitcham and Morden in 1982 - a result which prefaced a landslide general election victory the following year. The Party faces two crucial by-elections this week (Photo: Getty) 
With the party still tanking in national polls, Labour MPs are privately speculating that Mr Corbyn will quit before the next election. 
The poll also found the vast majority of Brits don’t want to see Donald Trump given a full state visit. Read More Jeremy Corbyn pays for massive secret opinion poll on his leadership 
Some 37% of those polled don’t believe Britain should roll out the red carpet for Donald Trump with a full state visit, and a further one in five (16%) think he should be barred from entering the country altogether. 
Just under a third of those polled thought he should get a state visit, with 65% of those that do identifying themselves as Ukip voters. Read More
